repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
- Render Lua types in api.txt.

- Added `DictAs(name)` API type which acts the same as `Dict` (no parens)
  when generating the dispatchers, but acts the same as `Dict(name)`
  when generating docs.

- Added `Tuple(...)` API type which is the treated the as `Array` for
  generating the dispatchers, but is used to document richer types.

- Added `Enum(...)` API type to better document enums

- Improve typing of some API functions.

- Improve c_grammar to properly parse API types and replace string pattern
  logic in the parsers.

- Removed all the hardcoded type overrides in gen_eval_files.lua

comment_data.body: `ArrayOf(Tuple(String, Union(String, Integer)))` would be more correct (in case that's supported).
Uncrustify gets confused here. Probably due to too many nested macros.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -968,8 +968,11 @@ static void build_cmdline_str(char **cmdlinep, exarg_T *eap, CmdParseInfo *cmdin
 ///                   - force: (boolean, default true) Override any previous definition.
 ///                   - preview: (function) Preview callback for 'inccommand' |:command-preview|
 /// @param[out] err Error details, if any.
-void nvim_create_user_command(uint64_t channel_id, String name, Object command,
-                              Dict(user_command) *opts, Error *err)
+void nvim_create_user_command(uint64_t channel_id, String name, Union(String,
+                                                                      LuaRefOf((DictAs(
+                                                                                      create_user_command__command_args)
+                                                                                args)))
+                              command, Dict(user_command) *opts, Error *err)

comment_data.body: (off topic) this is an example where [operator overloading](https://www.inf.puc-rio.br/~roberto/lpeg/#cap-num) is obfuscating more than helping
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -156,7 +183,7 @@ local api_param_type = (
 local ctype = C(
   opt(word('const'))
     * (
-      typed_container
+      typed_container / 0

comment_data.body:
I agree. The entirety of lpeg is like this. For common parsers like "optional" I've abstracted these away:

```lua
--- @param pat vim.lpeg.Pattern
local function opt(pat)
  return pat ^ -1
end

--- @param pat vim.lpeg.Pattern
local function rep(pat)
  return pat ^ 0
end

--- @param pat vim.lpeg.Pattern
local function rep1(pat)
  return pat ^ 1
end

local any = P(1)
```

Could do the same for `/ 0` but decided not to.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -156,7 +183,7 @@ local api_param_type = (
 local ctype = C(
   opt(word('const'))
     * (
-      typed_container
+      typed_container / 0

comment_regular_data.body:
> Added `Tuple(...)` API type  ... `Enum(...)` API type to better document

This is fine for docs and lua type hints, but we probably should not graduate these into formal RPC API types without first discussing the implications wrt `:help api-contract`. Introducing narrower types in the API could make it harder to augment the API.

> This is fine for docs and lua type hints, but we probably should not graduate these into formal RPC API types without first discussing the implications wrt :help api-contract. Introducing narrower types in the API could make it harder to augment the API.

Yes, I have no intention to make these official.

There is a slight problem though. The current api types test fixture has a few `ArrayOf` in there and I've added more here. This prevents me from renormalizing the types to the underlying `Dict`, `Array`, `String` etc without the test failing.

> The current api types test fixture has a few `ArrayOf` in there and I've added more here.

what test fixture? is this about the `api_info()` result ?

Yes.

I figured I can normalise `ArrayOf` -> `Array` on the test side similar to what you did for `Dictionary` -> `Dict`.

title: docs(api): document types using LuaCATS types
